title: How to write articles quickly - Quora

response.answer_text: 7 Tips for Writing a Good Article Quickly In the age of the internet, article writers who can generate good content in a short time period are in increasingly high demand. However, writing articles or blogging under tight deadlines should not come at the expense of good writing. Here is a step-by-step guide full of great tips to help you write a good article in record time:  Keep a list of ideas handy. You never know when writer’s block will hit. That’s why it’s important to keep a list of ideas for potential news articles or personal stories that could be expanded into essays. Any time you have an idea, jot it down in a notebook or in a Word document on your computer. That way, when it’s time to start writing, you’ll already have a place to start.Eliminate distractions. A lot of people claim to work better while multitasking. Rarely is this actually the case, especially if the goal is to write an entire article in a short amount of time.Research efficiently. Research is important for any piece of writing, but it’s also easy to fall into the trap of spending too much time researching and not enough time writing your first draft. If you’re looking for facts or statistics to support your argument, try to be as specific as possible in your search terms. If you aren’t finding the support you’re looking for, the takeaway may be that you need to adjust your thesis or subject matter.Keep it simple. A reader’s attention span is generally short, so one of the best things that you can do as a writer is to keep your article direct and concise. Having a maximum word count goal will help you not only help you complete your write-ups faster, but it will also result in a streamlined article that focuses on major points while eliminating fluff.Try writing in bullet points. Writing in bullet points can help you organize your thoughts and complete the article faster. Also, bullet point articles often drive higher traffic, since search engine algorithms tend to prioritize articles with bullet points and subheadings. Writing in bullet points is not only a time-saver, it can also increase the likelihood your article reaching your target audience.Edit after writing. One of the most common mistakes that writers make is trying to edit while they write. Resist this urge. Trying to edit while in the process of writing can slow you down, increasing the likelihood that you won’t even make it past the intro. Good writers know that writing and editing are two distinct and separate processes.Set a timer. A great way to become a quicker and more efficient writer is to practice writing to a timer. Set a timer for 30 minutes and see how much you can get done. You’ll be surprised how much you can produce during a half hour of focused, uninterrupted writing.

The two keys to writing quickly are to have a clear process and a clear head. When aiming to write blog articles that require research, the key is to break the process down over time. Our minds process information in 5 different ways to write a blog article. The brain can’t think four ways at once. So plan on a 5 step process, with breaks. Here are the steps. Create a concept or title from the purpose of your article.Do initial research by getting to know the subject well.Create an outline so you will have an organized presentation.Do detailed research so you have enough to write about.Write the post to a finished first draft.Some notes: If you are writing several posts on one general topic, you can do steps 1 and 2 for many blog posts at the same time. Then line up the titles and concepts, and, when it’s time to write, create an outline for each one.The end of this process is a finished draft. It still needs review, line editing and proofreading before it is published.If you know too much about your subject and you care a lot, you may need a different first step. You may need to do a brain dump to get it all out of your head. Write as if for a personal journal, with no thought of outline or publication. You can write for personal expression or as a diatribe. The focus of this writing is to get through the feeling “I have so much to say.” Once you do that, go back, create outlines, and then extract content from your brain dump and revise it to finish the post.Raqib, thanks for the A2A. This process has worked for me on hundreds of articles and blog posts, and I’ve taught it to hundreds of people, too. Enjoy the writing!

I can only tell you how I do it. I find an article online that has some of the more salient points I wish to make. That article will become part of my research and will provide inspiration for the article I wish to write. Make no mistake about one thing, though. Do not copy or even paraphrase any article. That’s plagiarism and it’s wrong. What you do is use the article as inspiration so as to cut down on the thinking time that always comes before the actual writing because looking at how someone else did what you are thinking of doing will give you ideas for your own article that you might otherwise have spent a lot of time figuring out. And it will shorten the research and writing time because you’ll more than likely have come up with a firm direction for your own article after reading someone else’s take on the subject, which also cuts down on time. Then write your article. You will discover that it is completely different from the one you read for inspiration and it will be done fairly quickly.

I’m assuming your context is blogging. The trouble with most people is they’re taking to the writing in the general mould of an academic writing effort — instead of treating it as “copy creation.” It would’ve been easier for anyone to just sit next to me and watch how I go about racing through the copy-making process. Some of my followers on Quora have seen me produce a whacking big answer for a question “asked just now” within a space of 15 or so minutes. If I had a ‘process,’ it would probably be describable as this:— When you have no time to do an outline The ideal situation is to have a written outline. Sometimes it’s impossible — sometimes you’re not in the mood too. Just settle for a mental outline. Put in placeholder “reminders” for the running order of things for now:— [lede] [main issue: smokers don’t know jack about what they’re smoking] [profile of smokers worldwide] [profiling smokers in 6 countries] [the correct way to smoke] [the wrong way to smoke] [who gives a damn] [who doesn’t give a damn] [what everybody’s conclusions are] [to hell with their conclusions — here’s my conclusion] Write a working headline first. Just shove in a quick headline that roughly indicates your general topic matter. Once you finish the writeup, return to the headline and rewrite it. If you can’t think of one, just skip it. Write the middle parts first. During the writeup, your entire existence as a human being is to write the middle parts first. Just write the stuff according to your understanding or beliefs — no matter how right or wrong they are. Put in your self-invented stuff as placeholders for the time being — leave the amendments for later after researching. Use ALLCAPS for stuff that needs updating later. The population of the UK is XXX million with XXX% men and XXX% women as at [DATE] 2017. Male smokers are more in the habit of SMOKING IN ALL SITUATIONS and female smokers ONLY IN SOCIAL SITUATIONS. You don’t have the flamin’ time to get the right figures or details right now. You get the copy done up to completeness or near-completeness first. Then write the ending. Conclusions are optional. If you need one, put it in. Otherwise, take the nearest exit. People don’t care to read “essays.” They prefer to read ‘stories.’ You don’t have to believe me — but you’ll find out the truth soon enough. Leave the wretched writeup alone. Stop writing and stop thinking about it — even if it’s for just 30 minutes or an hour. Walk around the house. Kick the pets. Have a drink. Eat some junk food. Now think about how you’re going to “fix” your copy with reasonably believable data. This is the part you start thinking about research. Do your ‘research.’ It’s impossible to plan and work at the same time. It’s impossible to research and write at the same time either. People who say it’s possible is just … impossible people. Clean up the copy, add your elements, and finalise. Once you’ve got all the “facts” (including lies published elsewhere), then feed the crap into your writeup. Then shove in some pictures to separate out your various sections. Add in subheads to break up long copy. Put in links where needed. Regularise your spellings, stylistics and grammar (in that order). Now write the ‘lede’ (the intro) — and publish! Always write the intro last. That’s because you now have an overall mental picture of the whole writeup. Now you can summarise the whole caboodle into 20–25 words that tug at the hearts and minds of your incredibly gullible readers. Use a fresh post to correct and update your post. Don’t go back to correct your published post. Publish a fresh post with a link pointing back to the published post. In the old post, put in “update lines” (links) in the relevant places that point to your fresh update post. Example:— In the fresh post:— “In last Tuesday’s post [embed the link], we have been reliably told by British Prime Minister Teresa “Bloody Difficult” May that the UK in fact has 31 men and the rest are women — all 64,999,969 women.” In the old post:— The population of the UK is 65 million with 49.99% men and 50.01% women as at 15 May 2017. (Update: It’s actually 31 men and the rest all women [embed link to fresh post].) FINAL WORD If you’ve got the cojones, just give yourself a fixed absolute maximum of 2 hours to do a writeup from start to finish. At the end of the 2 hours, just publish — for real — regardless of quality. A lot of famous bloggers with 10 or 20 years’ experience do exactly that. It puts a cap to the effort and stop things from dragging on. Over time, your writing will just improve by force. Thanks for the A2A.

There are already five beautiful answers and lot has been suggested. I know writing fast anything is not easy. I have done that but only sporadically. If I have to do that, I will immediately have in my mind the outline of what I have to write. Jot down points first. Material searching at that time is usually not done. Then I start with the open line and the first para. Then I have my closing sentence and the last para. I will have to fill in the main body as per my skeleton jotting. I have to do it in one sitting, or probably in three at the maximum. Second part revolves around writing the other paras, usually four to five more. I keep thinking about the material I have to sift from internet or some books that are available with me. Magazines can also offer help, if I have retained a few. Last and final sitting is the subject aligning and beautification. Editing is done along with word repetition avoidance. grammatical and composition parts are simultaneously worked upon. Before posting, a final reading is essential, despite editing is done. THAT HELPS REMOVE THE KINKS, ADD SMOOTHNESS AND RAISE THE IMPACT LEVEL. After a few articles, the quality is doubled. That is how I have experienced it. At the end, for prolific writing, one has to have off-line pieces written for future usage. These can be cut/pasted and edited to improve upon time and efficiency. Thanks for a2a.

The answer is to make your articles shorter. To do this, research a subject and build an outline of all you're interested in on that subject. Make your blog entry talk about one point in your outline. Make your blog entry longer by including a photo and a video. Make sure you link to at least one high traffic source like a .gov webpage, especially for definitions. After doing all the research, write the long piece, an article covering all the points, but divide each segment into nifty blogs before you post. You can even write all the blogs, then schedule them for release, using, next up, and previously discussed cliff hangars that make people want to come back. Really, with blogging, people really are looking for traffic--that's why they keyword the photos, the title, the video, the definition, and subpoints with the same keyword. Example: Outline for my flower garden: Spring Color Back borderMid borderLeafy fillerFront borderArt objectAnimal friendlyYou do a garden design, or find one at a popular garden, you explain the plants each blog, you define the terms using a popular gardening sites, include your own pictures, link to a book used on Amazon or Goodreads or both, include a video about care for that plant. You then have a 3000+ word article that can be separated into 7+ blogs, you post them all after you write them on Sunday, after researching it on Saturday, schedule them a day apart, then go work on something useful for the rest of the week. There is really no reason to have a blog (other than ego) unless you have something to sell. The web servers are set up to list commercial sites higher because they generate more ad sales. Naked women always generate sales, if you want that kind of reputation.

Time is the most precious resource, so I understand your consternation. On the other hand, while I have not read your writing, I appreciate your process. Some writers can be both prolific and profound, but they are a select few. Some writers produce copious amounts of crap. As you continue to write, your area of expertise will deepen and possibly widen. You will need less time to research. As for the research you are doing now, create a filing system - physical, mental, cyber or a combination of these so when you need information, you don’t repeat your research. your research is like a financial investment. At first, each deposit seems insignificant, but given time, you will find you have built up a solid nest egg. The research you do today may well serve you well tomorrow.
You have to write articles in which you are having depth knowledge then it will not take much time.
